 -79- ANNEX 2.10 ANNEX 2.10: FINANCIAL REPORTING AND AUDITING:' GUIDELINES AND TERMS OF REFERENCE 1. Introduction. The guidelines and terms of reference for financial reporting and auditing as detailed below will be applied to the China Animal Feed Project. In addition to the financial and auditing documentation required, the financial intermediary CADTIC, as the financial manager of the project, will refer to the financial covenants pertaining to CADTIC as stated in the loan's project agreement. 2. As the principal project manager on behalf of the sponsoring Ministry of Agriculture, the National Feed Industry Office (NFIO) will make reference to any of the fmancial and auditing reports referred to above, pertaining to project management, training, and other responsibilities related to project implementation. This will also include parts of the performance indicators outlined in Annex1r2 of the SAR. A. GUIDELINES 3. Auditing methods determine how and when financial transactions are recognized, calculated, classified, posted, summarized and ultimately reported. Accounting standards are formal guidelines that specify how certain types of transactions or events are to be recorded and what disclosures should be made in the footnotes to fuiancial statements. Acceptable accounting standards, (a) provide for full accountability for all funds by the Bank and other lenders, (b) result in adequate financial statement disclosures including a clear statement of the accounting policies adopted, (c) ensure fair presentation of financial performance and position, and (d) be acceptable to the Bank-approved auditors. CADTIC's accounting system should facilitate recording of financial transactions and timely financial reporting. Adequate systems should be in place prior to the commencement of project-related expenditures. If CADTIC proposes to use Statements of Expenditures (SOEs) as part of the procedure for withdrawing project loan proceeds, the Bank will specifically assess its systems and procedures for processing and maintaining support documentation for expenditures claimed on the SOEs. 4. Financial Reporting. Financial project reports to the Bank should contain a signed confirmation of their accuracy and veracity by an authorized representative of the borrower. Additionally, the Bank may require audits of the financial reports submitted. See also the Bank publication Guidelines on Financial Reporting and Auditing ofProjects Financed by the World Bank, July 1992.
 -80- ANNEX 2.10 Financial reports are classified into two categories: project-specific financial statements and executing agency financial statements. The Bank generally requires annual (and sometimes, interim) reporting on the sources and applications of funds in order to monitor the use of Bank proceeds. These reports should reflect activity both for the most recent reporting period and on a cumulative basis, and generally take the form of statements of cash receipts and expenditures. To assist in overcoming cash flow problems, a Special Account (SA) can be set up that will be replenished by the Bank periodically, based on the appropriate documentation received from the borrower. To assist in monitoring the use of an SA the Bank will require periodic statements from MOF of Account activity. For executive agency financial statements, the Bank requires commercially-prepared annual corporate financial statements, in order to monitor the agency's financial position and cost management. Such statements will comprise a balance sheet, income statement and cashflow statement. 5. Auditing Considerations. Auditors can be classified into three basic types: financial statement audits, compliance audits, and operational audits. The basic objective of a financial statement audit is to have independent auditors express an opinion on the overall fairness of presentation of the financial statements, thereby adding credibility to these statements. Compliance audits encompass review, testing and appraisal of controls and operating procedures in an organization. In commercially- oriented enterprises these review normnally involve accounting, financial and other operations as a service to management. For governmental organizations such reviews also cover compliance with regulations, contracts and laws to which these organizations are subject. Compliance audits of private and sate-owned enterprises are normally performed by internal auditors who are employees of the enterprise. Operational audits are more comprehensive examinations of an organization's management, techniques and performance. The objective of such audits is to measure the extent to which certain objectives are met. The primary report of an operational audit is a report recommending improvements to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of operations. Such audits are performed by all types of auditors, including internal auditors. B. TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR AUDITS 6. Auditing Requirements. Audit reports will be submitted by CADTIC to the Bank within six months following the fiscal year-end of CADTIC. Audit reports for subproject-specific statements, SOEs, and SA statements should be submitted within four months of the close of CADTIC's fiscal year. Compliance with the timeliness of financial reporting is important. The Bank reserves the right to refer back to the borrower the report of any auditor it may consider unresponsive to the agreed objectives or scope of the audit. 7. The annual audit will contain the following financial reports: (a) Project Financial Statements. Consolidated annual audits for all cash receipts and disbursements for the year and on a cumulative basis.
 - 81- ANNEX 2.10 (b) Executive Agency Financial Statements. Annual audit reports prepared in conformance with internationally accepted accounting standards will be required. Such audits will be performed by an independent auditor or audit firm, acceptable to the Bank, and will include a balance sheet, income statement, statement of changes in financial position, all with appropriate footnotes, and a Management Letter. (c) Special Accounts. An annual audit, including tests to establish of use of the SA complied with loan legal agreements, may be required upon Bank request, if exarnination of the SOEs warrants this audit. This is especially important since disbursements from the SA are made by the borrower prior to submission of SOEs or withdrawal applications to the Bank. (d) Reports on Internal Control. The Bank will require the borrower to request an auditor to prepare a Management Letter or report, outlining progress made in achieving the recommendations made by the Bank for the strengthening of institutional and operational constraints as described in paras. 2.28-2.29 of the Staff Appraisal Report. Where this audit addresses irregularities, specific terms of reference for the alleviation of same would be included. (e) Financial Covenants. The audit should verify compliance with all financial covenants pertaining to CADTIC, as stated in Schedule 1 of the Project Agreement. (f) Performance Indicators. The audit report will contain verification, or information to the contrary, on the financial performance indicators set out for CADTIC's performance in Annex 3.2 of the Staff Appraisal Report. C. SUBPROJECT PERFORMANCE 8. CADTIC, as a part of its ongoing monitoring of subproject performance, will furnish to the Bank by July I of each year for each Investment Enterprise and Investment Project financed under this project a copy of its previous annual audit prepared in accordance with the Project Agreement. Each said audit report will be accompanied by a summary report of CADTIC's evaluation of the subproject's performance which, anong other things, will include an evaluation of the subproject's performance and viability indicators as contained in Annex 3.2 of the Staff Appraisal Report and a report on the subproject's compliance with major loan covenants or other remedial measures imposed on the subproject by CADTIC. D. PROGREss REPORTS 9. Project Progress Report. In addition to the above audit reports, annual progress reports will be prepared by NFIO, utilizing its own and CADTIC documentation concerning project progress. The report will include three principal sources of
 - 82 - ANNEX 2.10 information: (a) updated performance indicators, (b) monitoring and evaluation reports, and (c) annual and cumulative implementation progress of project disbursement and activities. Technical reports and explanatory notes concerning project implementation progress will also be attached. During the first two years comprising CADTIC's institutional strengthening program, progress reports prepared by CADTIC concerning these activities will also be included. 10. Report on Statements of Expenditure. The SOEs of all contracts above a value of $5 million would be examined by postreview during supervision missions. MOF will, as a routine matter, verify 5 percent of all SOEs issued under the Project, and present its findings in the form of a report attached to the annual supervision progress report. SOEs are required to provide assurances to the propriety and eligibility of expenditures for reimbursement under the loan legal agreements. Prior Bank approvals will be necessary for disbursements of contracts over the amounts defined in the Loan Agreement and include all ICB and NCB contracts of $5 million or more, as well as all contracts for proprietary goods, contracts for consulting services in excess of $100,000 for firms and $50,000 for consultants. Prior review is also required for the first subloans to be approved for each of the seven project components. An audit may be necessary at the Bank's request to verify that claimed expenditures were properly supported and to confirm the Bank's reliance upon SOEs as a basis for disbursing loan proceeds.

 - 94 - ANNEX 3.1 ANNEX 3.1: ONLENDING TERMS AND CONDITIONS FOR THE PROJECT'S FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY, THE CHINA AGRIBUSINESS DEVELOPMENT TRUST AND INVESTMENT CORPORATION 1. Introduction. The Government of China and the World Bank have agreed to the designation of the China Agriculture Development Trust and Investment Corporation (CADTIC) as the financial intermediary for the Animal Feed Project. A Project Management Office within the National Feed Industry Office (NFIO) will provide overall coordination and guidance for project implementation. A Project Coordination Committee will be established under the Chairmanship of the Vice-Minister of Agriculture for Science and Technology to oversee project implementation. The purpose of the present document is to set out the terms and conditions under which loan proceeds would be onlent to eligible beneficiaries. 2. Scope of the Terms and Conditions. These onlending terms and conditions include the following topics: borrower eligibility; activity eligibility, loan security, interest and charges, maturity, and special conditions. Other matters such as CADTIC loan processing procedures, procurement and disbursement are addressed separately. The following terms and conditions will apply to subloans under this Project, subject to the provisions of the Project and Loan Agreements with the Bank. 3. Subborrower Eligibility. To be eligible to receive a loan under the Animal Feed Project, an applicant must satisfy the following criteria: (a) Will normally have been engaged in the animal feed industry including related ingredient supply and service enterprises for at least three years prior to application. (b) Be a separate legal entity, whether private enterprise, township and village enterprise, or state-owned enterprise. (c) Have prepared an enterprise transformation workplan outlining a time- based approach to the establishment of a corporate structure with autonomous management, modernized accounting systems, and business operations responsive to free market principles. Transformation should cover the following criteria: (i) restructuring toward autonomous management; (ii) modernization of accounting systems; and (iii) eventual divestment of social obligations.
 -95- ANNEX 3.1 (d) Have operated profitably for the three years preceding its application for project assistance. (e) Be able to provide not less than 30 percent of total project costs from new equity contributions. (f) Be able to demonstrate the ability to provide adequate working capital to assure successful implementation of the project. 4. In addition, subborrowers should meet the standard eligibility criteria to borrow from CADTIC. Specifically, the enterprise: (a) must demonstrate viable financial performance in terms of (i) continuous profitability for at least the last three years of operation; (ii) adequate solvency to meet current liabilities in a timely manner; and (iii) a debt- equity ratio of not more than 3:1. (b) Must possess the management, technical and other capabilities to implement the proposed project; and (c) Should not have defaulted on any of its outstanding debt obligations. 5. Activity Eligibility. To be eligible to receive a loan under the Animal Feed Project, an activity must satisfy the following criteria: (a) Is part of animal feed production, distribution and use, including ingredients, and/or essential support services. (b) Addresses one of the following constraints to the development of that industry: (i) Alleviates a supply constraint of a critical ingredient; (ii) Makes greater economic use of available raw materials; (iii) Contributes to improvement in the quality or efficiency of industrial processes, through improved technology or materials; (iv) Improves the organizational efficiency of the industry through specialization and integration. (c) Is capable of demonstrating financial viability, as determined by CADTIC, including among other factors: (i) Internal rate of return of not less than 12 percent; and (ii) Debt service cover of not less than 2: 1.
 - 96 - ANNEX 3.1 (d) Must conform to existing environmental, health and safety standards and regulations. (e) Where resettlement and land acquisition are required for a subproject, a resettlement plan meeting principles and procedures satisfactory to the Bank will be prepared as a condition of subloan approval by CADTIC, and where more than 200 persons are affected, the Bank's prior approval of such plans would be required. 6. Loan Security. CADTIC will require collateral for its subloans under this project consistent with its practices for similar enterprise and activities outside the Project. 7. Foreign Exchange Risk. Subloans may be denominated in foreign exchange, in renminbi or in a combination thereof. Foreign exchange risk shall be bome by the subborrower in the case of subloans or portions thereof denominated in foreign exchange, and by CADTIC for the foreign exchange equivalent of amounts disbursed, in the case of subloans or portions thereof denominated in renminbi. 8. Interest Rate and Other Charges. For subloans denominated in foreign exchange, the interest rate to be charged to subborrowers under the project shall be the rate at which funds are lent to CADTIC plus an operating margin of 2.3 percent, consisting of 1.2 percent administrative costs, 0.5 percent loss reserve, 0.5 percent profit margin, and a 0.1 percent PMO management fee. For subloans denominated in renminbi, the interest rate shall be the prevailing rate for term loans at the time a subloan is approved. 9. All subprojects will also be charged a project management fee, at the rate of 0.10 percent of outstanding loan balances, to be used for the operations of the Project Management Office. This fee shall be charged and collected at the same time as interest charges, but shall be separately recorded in CADTIC's accounts. Use of these funds shall be governed by the operating procedures of the PMO to be agreed before Project approval by the World Bank, and approved annual work plans. 10. Serious efforts will be made to ensure that interest rates to be charged will remain generally positive in real terms and that, on the proviso that an operating margin of 2.3 percent will be ensured, such rates will not be lower than prevailing rates charged for similar loans. In addition, CADTIC may levy fees for the following specific services and functions in accordance with its established practice. 11. Corporate Services. Charges for corporate financial services that CADTIC may provide, either on a voluntary basis to interested clients or as part of the special conditions required to meet loan approval criteria, shall be charged and recovered separately from the foregoing fees. Fees will be set so as to cover the full cost of these services when extended to clients under the Animal Feed Project. For other clients, fees will be set so as to generate a reasonable margin over costs.
 - 97 - ANNEX 3.1 12. Loan Maturity. Loan maturity shall not exceed seven years, and may include a grace period of up to 24 months, during which loan interest will be paid. Within these limits, the governing factor in determining the maturity on any specific subloan shall be the nature of the project and its projected cash flow as determined by CADTIC. 13. Special Conditions. CADTIC may require the borrower to comply with special conditions on a subloan to mitigate specific weaknesses in what is otherwise a sound investment proposal. Such conditions will normally have the effect of ensuring that available resources of the enterprise are preserved for the interest of the project investment. They may include, but are not limited to, the following: (a) Limitations on the distribution of earnings; (b) Limitations on expenditures for employee social welfare perquisites; (c) Limitations on the disposition of fixed assets or the acquisition of new fixed assets; (d) Conduct of banking services with a designated bank; (e) Limitations on borrowing from other sources; (f) Requirement to maintain management and business policies acceptable to CADTIC; and, (g) Requirements to maintain certain financial factors of the borrower's business at specified levels, such factors including but not limited to working capital and owners' equity. 14. Special Provisions for Existing NFIO Pipeline. NFIO, in cooperation with the World Bank, has developed a pipeline of projects that satisfy the sector objectives of the project, and that appear, generally, to be technically and commercially sound. The creditworthiness of sponsors and financial viability of proposed activities has been only partially examined, and there is a range of quality among these 30 cases. Under the project, priority will be given to completing the evaluation of these subprojects, and special arrangements will be made to ensure adequate attention to the potential they represent. 15. CADTIC recognizes that a significant amount of work has already been performed by NFIO and others to identify and evaluate enterprises and projects that may be viable candidates for subloans under the Animal Feed Project. Conversely, NFIO recognizes that CADTIC cannot approve subloans that do not conform to the criteria established for the project or its own financial security. To ensure prompt attention to completing the appraisal of these proposals, and to ensure that every opportunity is given to sponsors to qualify for participation in the Project, the procedure outlined below will be followed. A Joint Task Force will be established by CADTIC and NFIO to undertake
 - 98 - ANNEX3.1 a preliminary evaluation of these dossiers. The result of this evaluation should be a classification of all applications into one of three groups: Group A Projects which appear to be creditworthy. Group B Projects that may be creditworthy, but which are presently deficient in one or more areas. Group C Projects that are grossly deficient in satisfying CADTIC's lending criteria, and that are unlikely to correct those deficiencies within a reasonable time. Such enterprises may reapply at some later date subject to the availability of funds under the project. 16. NFIO members of the Task Force will be responsible to: (a) ensure that all documentation prepared to date is readily available to CADTIC members; (b) facilitate consultations between all members and the subsponsors; (c) provide background and explanations on technical and sector issues in respect of each proposal; (d) assist sponsors to respond to requests from CADTIC; (e) confirm from all potential sponsors that they (i) are prepared to engage in corporate commercialization, (ii) have available a sound, technical proposal, and (iii) are willing to undertake the necessary environmental and resettlement studies, where relevant; (f) draft technical and commercial sections of the preliminary evaluation report. 17. CADTIC members of the Joint Task Force will be responsible to: (a) review technical and commercial aspects of proposals and request points of correction or clarification; (b) examine sponsor creditworthiness, including not only conventional financial measures, but giving due weight to local government support and other factors that are significant in the Chinese context. (c) identify specific weaknesses in applications that are determined not to be ready for immediate processing, and recommend remedial measures, where possible, to remove the constraint.
 - 99- ANNEX 3.1 (d) draft creditworthiness and viability sections of the preliminary evaluation and recommendations on measures to address deficiencies; (e) prepare the final grouping of applications, and advise sponsors in writing of the status of their applications. 18. CADTIC and NFIO members of the Task Force will prepare their respective sections of the written report of the preliminary evaluation, and CADTIC will carry out the final grouping. Any unresolved differences between members on factual or analytical grounds will also be reported in the first draft of this report. Senior representatives of MOA and CADTIC, as well as representatives of the World Bank team will be given two weeks to comment on these differences, following which CADTIC will make a final determination. 19. Subproject Sponsor Arbitration Procedure. Sponsors will be advised in writing of the results of this evaluation. CADTIC representatives will meet with all sponsors who wish to pursue their applications, as follows: (a) for Group A, to set out steps to complete appraisal and loan approval; (b) for Group B, to explain specific inadequacies and discuss remedial measures, including CADTIC assistance, as appropriate; and, (c) for Group C, to explain inadequacies and determine the sponsor's interest and capacity to undertake a remedial program. 20. Agreements reached during those discussions will constitute the basis for firther processing of these applications. Results will be reported in writing to the PMO and World Bank.
 -100 - ANNEX 3.2 ANNEX 3.2: PERFORMANCE INDICATORS 1. The major objectives of this project are: (a) to support domestic capacity building in the feed industry through predetermined groups of commodity production subprojects; (b) supported by an institution promoting feed sector development, in the form of the China Feed Industry Center (CFIC), involved in training, feed testing, feed sector policy development, technology acquisition and consultancies. The project will be: (c)financially intermediated, and (d) participating subproject enterprises will undertake several enterprise reform measures to render them more commercially operative. These four objectives, and project performance, form the set of criteria on which the project will be monitored and evaluated through a set of performance indicators. 2. Key performance indicators were developed for: (a) overall project performance, (b) financial intermediation, (c) subproject performance, (d) CFIC operations, and (e) enterprise reform. These will be measured at four intervals throughout and following the life of the project: (a) year of onset of implementation, (b) mid-term review, (c) ICR year, and (d) full-impact year. 3. Overall Project and Subproject Performance. Project performance is related to total project performance and subproject performance, environmental monitoring, and project management. Indicators for overall project performance include: project disbursement and procurement; subproject activation a's a measure of implementation speed, management performance indicators pertain to PMO management quality of the project's executive agency NFIO, and of its financial intermediary CADTIC.  -114- ANNEX s.2 ENTERPRISE ASSESSMENT, FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 1. Introduction. This Annex presents an example of the historical corporate analysis, and the determination of the financial and economic rates of return of one of the subprojects in the present pipeline. The subproject selected is the Guangdong Huada Machinery Works, a state-owned enterprise (Annex 2.7) manufacturing feed processing equipment and machine parts. The company's proposal involves the expansion of its factory to produce large-capacity feed processing equipment and spare parts. 2. The methodology of evaluation and analysis of all subprojects in the present pipeline has employed a standard format that has included, in chronological order of analysis: • Historical, financial and organizational assessment of the sponsoring enterprise * Technical assessment of the proposed subproject * Availability of sufficient corporate equity and counterpartfunds commitments * Financial and economical analysis of the proposed subproject 3. The above-listed analytic structure has formed the basis for accepting, rejecting or modifying proposals brought forward by interested enterprises. Where modifications were deemed feasible, recommendations for time-bound further work or remedial action were submitted to the enterprises in question. The indicators used in these assessments are presented in Annex 3.2, "Onlending Terms and Conditions." The project's financial intermediary, CADTIC (see Annex 3.1) has carried out a parallel appraisal of the subproject pipeline, using similar criteria as outlined above. 4. Assumptions. Most assumptions made in the financial and economic analyses have been described in the SAR text: (a) a standard conversion factor of 0.97 was used in economic analysis, calculated on the basis of an official exchange rate of Y 8.40 to $1.00 and a shadow exchange rate of Y 8.70 to $1.00 (paras. 5, 11), and (b) a table outlining the calculation of border prices for commonly used project commodities is presented in Annex 5.3. 5. Other Assumptions, as incorporated in the historical enterprise viability, and the financial and economic analyses, are outlined below.
 -115 - ANNEX 5.2 6. Historical Corporate Analysis. The main purpose of the historical analysis was the determine the profitability and managerial capability of the potential subproject sponsor. To achieve this, a coherent set of financial statements comparable to Western accounting standards was constructed, using either available information or data obtained from the sponsor. After having been converted into a Western format, the creditworthiness, profitability and production efficiency of each sponsor was determined. 7. Corporate Income Statement (Table A-2). This analysis is based on supporting tables, completed by each sponsoring enterprise, from which an Income Statement and a Balance Sheet were constructed. Each subproject sponsor was required to complete Tables A-3 through A-8 (see para. 8, Table 1, below). Individually, these tables provided financial details concerning the amount and prices of products sold, amount and cost of raw materials, labor, factory overhead, marketing expenses, general and administrative expenses, financing costs, and extraordinary income and expenses not associated with the subproject itself. Based on this data an income statement was derived in accordance with Western accounting standards. 8. Balance Sheet (Table A-8). Modern Chinese asset and liability accounting now follows a format similar to Western standards, which was employed in the determination of the balance sheet as subsequent analysis of the sponsor. 9. Financial Analysis. Assumptions made for this analysis include the following: (a) Construction Period: For expansion projects, 1 year. For new projects, 2 years, with certain exceptions. (b) Construction Cost: Cost estimates as supplied by sponsor, and verified by consultants. Interest during construction to be capitalized. (c) Revenues: 1995 prices verified. Quantities supplied by sponsor, based in annual averages. (d) Direct Costs: Based on estimates of annual averages, or projected from similar production lines. (e) Indirect Costs: Marketing: 1-2.5 percent of sales; and General and Administrative: 1-2.5 percent of sales. (f) Financing: For Bank loan: Based on standard variable interest IBRD rate of 7.25 percent. For counterpart funds: Based on local bank rate. Equity: Assuned to be noninterest-bearing contribution. (g) Taxes: Based in local taxation rates and on new (i.e., pioneer) or expansion project status. (h) Depreciation: Based on Chinese tax code.
 -116- ANNEX 5.2 (i) Capacity Utilization: For new projects: 50 percent at end of Year I following implementation; 75 percent for Year-end 2; 100 percent for Year- end 3. For expansion projects: 75 percent for Year-end 1; 100 percent for Year-end 2. 10. Economic Analysis. Constraints encountered in calculating economic prices included (a) the large number of diverse subprojects, (b) great variations in end-products and raw materials, and (c) the uniqueness in certain areas of a certain end-product or raw material. Economic prices were therefore calculated for major classes of representative end-products (Annex 5.3), and their coefficients applied to specific end-products most closely belonging to similar representative end-product classes. In all calculations, taxes, interest and depreciation were added back to income. 11. Subproject Categorization. Based on the analyses outlined above, CADTIC has categorized the entire pipeline, as it existed at appraisal, into three Groups based on their technical and financial viability (Anex 3J.1, para. 19). Further work will be required to convert weak proposals into acceptable ones, or to eliminate them for replacement by new proposals. The phasing of project implementation is based on the subproject categorization, which determines the order in which subprojects accepted for financing will become effective. 12.  -118 - ANNEX 5.2 SUMMARY OF ANALYSIS OF GUANGDONG HUADA MACHINERY WORKS' The Subproject This subproject would serve to expand its production line to an annual production of 10 production lines of 2.5 tph; eight units of premix blending equipment; 6,000 pelleting dies; 3,000 pelleting rollers; and 74 units of miscellaneous feed processing equipment. The investment cost will be Y 105.1 million, with a financial rate of return of 20.2 percent. Summary Company sales and profits are increasing while repayment capacity is sufficient for additional debt. Historical Performance Sales continued to grow until Year 9 when they reached Y 120.7 million. Gross mnargin, at approximately 40 percent (34 percent industry norm) is above industry standards. In Year 5, net income was positive and ranged between 24 and 35 percent (4.3 percent) of sales. Proposed Project Impact Project cash flow is projected positive in Year 3 and after Year 4, and the debt-to- cash flow ratio is 48 percent, 169 percent and 59 percent during the first three years of debt repayment. Thus, the project would not generate sufficient cash flow to cover debt repayment in Year 4 when principal payment come due. In terms of sensitivity analysis, the project would not be affected strongly by reductions in price or increases in direct costs. A 10 percent change in either variable would cause the project to continue to be profitable at a slightly lower level. The project's internal rate of return is based on a 10-year cash flow. The construction period is assumed to be two years. Production increases gradually rise as construction is completed. Production stabilized at Year 9. Loans terns comprise two years' grace when interest is capitalized, one year of interest only, and a five-year payback. The proposed IBRD rate is 9.25 percent as compared to a current local rate of 13.76 percent. Since this project is exempt from income taxes, none have been assumed. Analysis Sales (real) and operating profits increased 20 percent per year from 1991 to 1994. Operating profit margins, at 14.4 percent (4 percent) are three times the industry norm, primarily the result of lower operating expenses. Slight imbalances are present among the major asset classes of the balance sheet. Relative to total assets, current assets are lower and current liabilities are higher than a typical firm of the same asset size. As a result, the current ratio, at 1:1.6, is lower than expected. However, equity is 38 percent (39.8 percent), which is adequate. Times interest ratio is 2.9 (2.7), which is slightly above the norm. This indicates a sufficient cushion exists for either interest rate increase or more debt. Remedial Action No special intervention appears necessary at this time, other than the assurance of short-term financing to cover the expected cash flow deficit in Year 4.

doc.abstracts: The overall objectives of the Animal Feed Project are the following: 1) alleviation of supply constraints of critical feed ingredients; 2) improvement and expansion of the utilization of agroindustrial byproducts for use as high-quality livestock feeds; 3) improvement of the organizational efficiency of the feed sector through specialization and integration; and 4) restructuring of project enterprises to effect greater corporate efficiency and commercialization. The project is essentially a financial intermediation operation directed toward increasing supply constraints and strengthening the feed sub-sector infrastructure, and comprises six types of domestic feed ingredient or service capacity building sub-projects or components and one feed sub-sector strengthening component. The six capacity building components include: 1) integrated feed and livestock production; 2) feed additives manufacture; 3) feed protein crop production; 4) feed processing equipment design and manufacture; 5) enhanced-protein feed product synthesis; and 6) feed commodity wholesale marketing.
